div1.p: Black discusses the relationship between Gorgas and Ludlow.

div1.head: Letter from William M. Black to Jefferson Randolph Kean, February 3, 1925
div1.opener:
MAJ. GEN. W. M. BLACK, U. S. A., RETIRED
CHARLES A. McKENNEY
JOHN STEWART
ADDRESS ALL COMMUNICATIONS TO THE FIRM
TELEPHONE MAIN 5380>
CABLE ADDRESS: TRENAC
BLACK, McKENNEY AND STEWART
ENGINEERS
1653 PENNSYLVANIA AVE., N. W.
WASHINGTON, D.C.
February 3, 1925
General Jefferson R. Kean,
Army Medical Museum,
7th and B Sts., S.W.,
Washington, D.C.
My dear Kean:
div1.p:
I have read over your review with very great interest.
On examination of the annual reports of General Ludlow and
General Wood, I find that General Gorgas was Chief Surgeon of
the Department of Havana until that Department was abolished
on April 30th, 1900. Major Davis was Chief Sanitary Officer
of the Department of Havana until February, 1900, when he was
transferred to Manilla. General Gorgas then succeeded him as
Chief Sanitary Officer of the Department. On May 1st, 1900,
General Gorgas became Chief Sanitary Officer of the Department
of Cuba. Colonel Havard was Chief Surgeon of the Department
of Cuba, and in so far as I can ascertain, remained in that
position until the close of the intervention. I do not see
that General Gorgas ever was Chief Surgeon.

I also think that you were wrong in stating that
General Ludlow did not support, and was not a friend of General
Gorgas. I knew General Ludlow very intimately, as you know, and
I don't remember any instance or statement which would warrant
your statement that he was not friendly to General Gorgas. It
is quite possible that General Gorgas himself may have felt un-
friendly to General Ludlow, but I do not think the reverse is
the case. I don't know anything about relations of the other
chiefs whom you mention to General Gorgas.

In regard to the cleaning of Havana. I think you can
make the statement stronger than you have. Havana was cleaned
in a physical sense, both as to streets and buildings, before
General Gorgas became Chief Sanitary Officer. After he became
Chief Sanitary Officer, he continued Dr. Davis' work in keeping
the private houses cleaned, and he should be credited with the
entire work of freeing the city from mosquitoes.

I enjoyed reading your review of the book very much, and
believe that you have done full justice to the subject, with the
exceptions noted above.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, W. M. Black,
Major General U.S.A., Retired Article changed Feb 4 to conform
to above-
J.R.K.
